content.user_title: Canvas Design: Museum-Quality Visual Art Generator
content.value_statement: Transform ideas into sophisticated visual art pieces by first establishing a design philosophy, then expressing it through expertly crafted posters, graphics, and design artifacts.
actual_capabilities: Creates original design philosophies/aesthetic movements as foundational frameworks
Generates high-quality PDF and PNG visual art based on established philosophies
Produces museum-quality posters, graphics, and design pieces with sophisticated aesthetics
Incorporates subtle conceptual references into abstract compositions
Uses custom typography from included font library (25+ open-source fonts)
Balances minimal text with strong visual communication
Creates multi-page design series or coffee table book-style collections
Emphasizes craftsmanship with expert-level composition, spacing, and color theory
limitations: Focuses on static visual output only (PDF/PNG), not interactive or animated designs
Requires interpretation of user intent to deduce subtle conceptual references
Limited to the fonts included in canvas-fonts directory
Best suited for abstract, artistic, and conceptual work rather than literal illustrations
Not designed for technical diagrams, infographics, or data-heavy visualizations

best_practices: Start by providing conceptual direction or aesthetic preferences to guide the philosophy creation
Request specific output format (PDF vs PNG) based on your use case
Specify page dimensions or aspect ratios if needed (poster, square, letterhead, etc.)
Be open to abstract interpretations rather than literal representations
For multi-page work, specify how many pages you want upfront
Reference existing design movements if you want to guide the aesthetic (Bauhaus, Swiss modernism, etc.)
Allow the skill creative freedom - it excels when given conceptual space
Review the design philosophy markdown to understand the aesthetic framework used
anti_patterns: Requesting literal illustrations or photorealistic imagery (not the skill's purpose)
Asking for heavy text content or information-dense layouts (contradicts minimal text philosophy)
Expecting clip-art style graphics or amateur aesthetics (focuses on museum-quality work)
Requesting animated or interactive elements (static output only)
Over-specifying exact visual details (limits the skill's interpretive strength)
Using for technical diagrams or data visualization (better suited for artistic expression)

faq.question: What's the difference between the design philosophy and the final output?
faq.answer: The design philosophy (markdown file) establishes the aesthetic movement and visual principles. The final output (PDF/PNG) is the actual artwork that expresses that philosophy visually. You receive both files.

faq.question: Can I request specific colors or fonts?
faq.answer: Yes, but the skill works best when you provide conceptual direction (e.g., 'muted earth tones' or 'bold modernist typography') rather than exact specifications. It has access to 25+ custom fonts in the canvas-fonts directory.

faq.question: How much text should appear in the final design?
faq.answer: The philosophy emphasizes minimal text - usually just key phrases, labels, or essential words integrated as visual elements. Think posters, not documents. Text is always sparse and design-forward.

faq.question: Can I use this for commercial projects?
faq.answer: The skill is licensed under Apache 2.0 and fonts use SIL Open Font License 1.1, which generally permit commercial use. Always review the LICENSE.txt and font-specific OFL files for complete terms.

faq.question: What if I want multiple variations?
faq.answer: Request a multi-page output upfront (e.g., '5 variations exploring the same concept'). The skill will create a cohesive series with distinct interpretations within the same aesthetic framework.

faq.question: How do 'subtle references' work?
faq.answer: The skill embeds conceptual DNA into the work - someone familiar with the subject might feel it intuitively, while others simply experience a masterful composition. It's sophisticated and niche, never literal.

permissions: File system access to read fonts from canvas-fonts directory
